title: Mulholland Dr. (8/10) Movie CLIP - This is the Girl (2001) HD

comments.text:
Love it. None of it is real. Brilliant and entertaining on all levels, this 
film.﻿

comments.text:
Lynch broke the mold Mulholland Dr. (8/10) Movie CLIP - This is the Girl 
(2001) HD﻿
comments.author: Big Andre'

comments.text:
Greatest film of all time.  If you watch it more than 3 times, you will 
figure it all out.  The last 30 minutes are the only real part, and the 
scenes are not in chronological order.  You have to piece it together with 
the clues (ashtray, key, blue box, etc.).  The majority of the film is a 
post-suicide fantasia explaining Diane Selwin's reasons for killing 
herself. ﻿
comments.author: Jeremy Trager

comments.text: Who is the girl at the beginning﻿

comments.text: cue every professional athelete
comments.author: zackhanscom

comments.text:
There are soo many layers to this movie, you can't just sit down and 
dissect this movie like you would any other and come up with a conclusion 
after a hand full of times, the second singer (blonde),why did she look as 
if she was not suppose to be there? When Adam looks back and sees 
Diane(Cammilla Rhodes) why does he have a look in his eyes like he would 
feather see her audition? When Naomi Watts was Cammilla, and forked over a 
bunch of cash, lastly what is the blue box and key all about, I've watch it 
with a scientific analytical mind frame. The clues I have are just a few 
out if hundreds. If your thinking fantasy I suggest you go back and take 
note of every little thing you saw﻿
comments.author: Bathory187

comments.text:

comments.text:
I agree the film industry needs films that make money to continue, but I'm 
saying crap like Transformers aren't the ones that should be making the 
money!! Why does America gravitate towards rehashed stories, mindless 
action, and vulgar comedies?? The majority of Americans are stupid. Films 
like There will be Blood, The Tree of Life, and Mulholland Drive should be 
making the money, and they would if Americans actually had intelligence.

comments.author: bphilippe92

comments.text:
Do you mean the guy at 4.23? The `actor' Angelo Badalementi -- actually a 
composer and the guy who composed the music for this and Twin Peaks and a 
number of Lynch films. He appeared earlier in the movie in the coffee scene 
-- `This is the Girl'.
comments.author: MrYossell

comments.text:
This film is like labyrinth. I've seen it four times and each time I come 
up away with a different narrative in my mind about what the film depicts. 
I think this is filmmaking at its best - Lynch's juxtaposition of kitsch 
50's culture with modern day, the optimism of Betty and bitterness and 
depression of Diane is amazing.
comments.author: Paul Dirac

comments.text:
can someone answer me please. I've been looking everywhere. The man who 
steps out of the shadow at the end, it's Philip Baker Hall isn't? I mean, 
his voice and face are exactly like Hall's. But he's not credited in 
Mulholland on IMDB.. nor everwhere..
comments.author: bphilippe92

comments.text:
Part of the reason this film is such a mindfuck is because it is 
incomplete. David Lynch made a pilot for a television show which never 
caught and he made this film. he admits that it is incomplete. i used to 
watch this film every day, have it on in the background, and have long 
intricate discussions about the plot...involving surreal fantasies and time 
loops...later to come upon new info from the man himself remarking how 
incomplete it is. that really broke my heart a little.
comments.author: AristurtlE

comments.text:
Indeed. That was well stated. Mulholland Drive is about dreams & 
nightmares. I have seen it at least eight times, not counting the various 
clips here.The first time I saw it, I didn't get it, the second time I 
didn't understand it either.After the third time & with the help of some 
synopsis's & reviews it slowly came to me.Then realized this is one of the 
most brilliant films I've ever seen. Betty is a fantasy of Diane Selwyn. 
Rita, was an imagination.She never existed.
comments.author: Walter Van der Wahl

comments.text:
His movies have gotten a little more docile in later years. I just watched 
Wild At Heart the other day. He has lost a little chutzpah since then, but 
that doesn't make them bad, just not as graphic.
comments.author: subsamadhi

comments.text:
(Okay I will explain this the best way i know how) I have not seen all of 
David Lynch films i have only seen a few, and it seems even in his films in 
the 2000s- like Mulholland Dr and Inland Empire that he still keeps this 
kind of retro style of feeling in his films. Like this scene right here 
with 50s or 60s style of singing.. I want to know dose he do this with all 
his work?
comments.author: Christhian Stubbs

this movie ist such a wunderful masterpiece - thanks Mister Lynch - it is

comments.text:

information is fucking bogus.

comments.text:
Hey, just here to listen to this great tune Mulholland Drive style, and 
noticed your comment here. Mindfuck movies are one thing, but I always saw 
Mulholland Drive as a movie that, although artsy, doesn't actually make a 
whole lot of sense overall. My reasoning for this is that (so far as I 
know), Mulholland Drive was originally meant as a TV series that didn't 
happen, therefore things that may have been explained later in the series 
remain a mystery, and the viewer is left confused. Thoughts?
comments.author: Augustine Jay

comments.text:

comments.text:
Adam (The director) is not getting a choice of who he's casting for the 
role, because the guys he said "This is the girl" to are essentially 
forcing him to cast Camilla. The plot to Mulholland Drive is incredibly 
complex and told in such a way that forces viewers to think about it. 
Instead of spoiling the experience, I recommend watching it. If you have 
Netflix, it's on there. It's one of the great mindfuckers out there, and 
one of my personal favorite films ever.
